items.title: Database Version
rows: Oracle Database 23ai Free Release 23.0.0.0.0 - Develop, Learn, and Run for Free Version 23.6.0.24.10

items.summary: Found 33 users using the DEFAULT profile.
items.title: Users with DEFAULT Profile
items.oneline: User accounts using the DEFAULT profile
items.details:
Following limits are defined by the DEFAULT profile: 

PASSWORD LIMITS:
PASSWORD_VERIFY_FUNCTION: NULL
INACTIVE_ACCOUNT_TIME: 365
PASSWORD_REUSE_TIME: UNLIMITED
PASSWORD_REUSE_MAX: UNLIMITED
PASSWORD_LOCK_TIME: 1
FAILED_LOGIN_ATTEMPTS: 10
PASSWORD_ROLLOVER_TIME: 0
PASSWORD_LIFE_TIME: 180
PASSWORD_GRACE_TIME: 7

RESOURCE LIMITS:
CPU_PER_CALL: UNLIMITED
COMPOSITE_LIMIT: UNLIMITED
SESSIONS_PER_USER: UNLIMITED
LOGICAL_READS_PER_SESSION: UNLIMITED
CONNECT_TIME: UNLIMITED
IDLE_TIME: UNLIMITED
PRIVATE_SGA: UNLIMITED
CPU_PER_SESSION: UNLIMITED
LOGICAL_READS_PER_CALL: UNLIMITED
items.remarks:
The CIS benchmark recommends against assigning users to the DEFAULT profile as the DEFAULT profile has UNLIMITED settings for all resources, allowing the user to launch a denial-of-service attack by exhausting all resources. 

The Oracle best practice is to update the DEFAULT profile to match organizational standards and use custom profiles to accommodate accounts that are an exception to the normal organizational standard.

New database users are assigned the DEFAULT profile unless another profile is explicitly assigned. 

Even though profiles can be used to limit resource consumption, such as CPU and memory, Oracle Database Resource Manager is recommended for its flexible means of managing and tracking resource use.

items.summary: No unlocked user accounts are using a default password.
items.title: Users with Default Passwords
items.oneline: User accounts should not have default passwords
items.remarks:
Default passwords for predefined Oracle accounts are well known and provide a trivial means of entry for attackers. Database or account administrators should also change well-known passwords for locked accounts. Having default passwords can lead to unauthorized data manipulation and theft of confidential information. 

Note that if a script creates the database and the SYS or SYSTEM user password remains unchanged, these users are considered to possess a default password. Your database may be at risk due to the password presence within the script. Change the password to improve security.

items.summary: No unlocked users found with password expired for more than 30 days.
items.title: Users with Expired Passwords
items.oneline: User accounts should not be inactive
items.remarks: Password expiration is used to ensure that users change their passwords regularly. Unlocked accounts with an expired password can present a security risk, especially as those accounts age. Although the password is expired, if the account is unlocked it can easily be used by anyone knowing the old password. You should investigate accounts that have been unused for an extended period to determine whether they should remain active.

items.summary: All user accounts will eventually lock when inactive. No unlocked users inactive for more than 35 days found.
items.title: Inactive Users
items.oneline: Infrequently used accounts should be locked or dropped
items.remarks: If a user account is no longer in use, it unnecessarily increases the system's attack surface while providing no corresponding benefit. Furthermore, unauthorized use is less likely to be noticed when no one uses the account regularly. Investigate accounts not used for more than 35 days to determine whether they should remain active. A solution is to set INACTIVE_ACCOUNT_TIME in the profiles assigned to users to automatically lock accounts that have not logged in to the database instance for a specified number of days, for example, 35 days. Audit infrequently-used accounts for unauthorized activities.

items.summary: Found 2 sample schemas.
items.title: Sample Schemas
items.oneline: Sample schemas should be dropped
items.details: Sample schemas: HR, SH
items.remarks: Sample schemas are well-known accounts provided by Oracle to serve as simple examples for developers. They generally serve no purpose in a production database and should be removed because they unnecessarily increase the attack surface of the database.

items.summary: No application owner found.
items.title: Application Owner Account
items.oneline: Evaluate authorizations to object owner account
items.remarks: Restricting access to application service/owner accounts is crucial, especially since these accounts typically hold sensitive data or highly privileged procedures and functions that can access and modify sensitive data. As a best practice, these accounts should be locked or converted into schema-only accounts. This prevents unauthorized users from accessing these accounts. You should audit these accounts' activity if, for any reason, they require interactive use. This finding lists the non-Oracle-maintained schema with the most number of objects.

items.summary: No user is found to share administrative privileges. No Proxy user found that shares another account.
items.title: Shared Accounts
items.oneline: User accounts should not be shared
items.remarks:
Having shared accounts to interact with the database may prevent the application from recording an individual user's identity used to read, insert, update and delete records. Use accounts assigned to individual users where feasible. You should audit shared or proxy users' activity. Configure user accounts, the database and/or the application to provide personal accountability. To accurately identify individual application users in connection pools, utilize the SET_IDENTIFIER procedure of DBMS_SESSION in SQL or the appropriate method/attribute in your programming language. Enterprise-packaged applications may have methods for achieving this, so check with the vendor and My Oracle Support for more information. It is also vital to monitor proxy users, who can connect to the database as their client users.

Also, you should not have accounts with multiple administrative privileges (sysdba, sysoper, sysbackup, sysdg, syskm). You should assign one administrative privilege per user account for better separation of duties. Users requiring to execute multiple administrative functions can have specific accounts for each activity type.

items.summary: Non-Oracle maintained users that own objects not found.
items.title: Users with Objects
items.oneline: Users who own objects
items.remarks: Object owners can control access to their objects through Discretionary Access Control (DAC). This is the default functionality in the Oracle Database. In general, no additional action is required. If desired, Database Vault can be utilized to enable or disable a user's DAC privileges on their objects.

items.summary: No users own database objects.
items.title: Users Authorized for Object Ownership
items.oneline: User accounts should be authorized to own objects
items.remarks: By default, users have complete control over the objects they own and can grant access to others. It is important to ensure that only documented and authorized users are allowed to own objects. Uncontrolled object ownership can result in unauthorized access, alterations, and modifications to data. Regularly review the account list for unauthorized ownership and reassign authorized objects to the appropriate authorized owner if needed.

items.summary:
Found 2 users who own security-related objects. Found 1 schema who own Program Units and can potentially call security-related functions.
Found 2 users who can access or modify security-related objects.
items.title: Users with Security Objects
items.oneline: Isolate program units that provide security functionality
items.details:
Users who own security-related objects: DVF, DVSYS
Schemas containing Program Units that can potentially invoke security-related calls: HR
Users who can access or modify security-related objects: GSMUSER, SYSBACKUP
items.remarks:
Stored procedures, functions, and packages that enforce or define security policies should be isolated from application code and data. An attacker can use system privileges (such as CREATE ANY TABLE, DROP ANY TABLE, ALTER ANY TABLE, INSERT ANY TABLE, DELETE ANY TABLE, UPDATE ANY TABLE, CREATE ANY PROCEDURE, DROP ANY PROCEDURE, ALTER ANY PROCEDURE, and EXECUTE ANY PROCEDURE) to manipulate security objects or data in the database. Please review PL/SQL code in functions, procedures, and packages that support security functions to determine in what schemas they are located and take appropriate action to isolate them in a separate schema. Ensure access to data through PL/SQL code that supports security functions does not exceed permitted authorization.

Oracle Label Security can tag program units as trusted and prevent unauthorized access to user data   when executed by a malicious user.

items.summary: No users found who have been granted privileges to perform security critical actions with grant option.
items.title: Users with Grant Option
items.oneline: Limit propagation of access rights
items.remarks: Account permission to grant privileges within the database is an administrative function. Minimizing the number and privileges of administrative accounts reduces the chances of privileged account exploitation. User accounts that require WITH GRANT OPTION privileges should belong to sanctioned users who can propagate access rights to important objects. Limiting the propagation of access rights ensures that users can't continuously grant access to objects they don't own without restriction.

items.summary: No user schema found that contains sensitive data as marked by TSDP.
items.title: Users with Sensitive Data
items.oneline: Check access granted on data marked sensitive by TSDP
items.remarks: In the current context, sensitive data refers to any data flagged as sensitive by Transparent Sensitive Data Protection (TSDP). To ensure secure access to sensitive information, it is best to grant access through roles rather than directly to individual accounts. Prompt revocation of access granted to individual accounts is recommended.

items.summary: No user data is stored in SYSTEM and SYSAUX tablespace by default.
items.title: User Schemas in SYSTEM or SYSAUX Tablespace
items.oneline: User accounts should not use SYSTEM or SYSAUX tablespaces
items.remarks: The SYSTEM and SYSAUX tablespaces are reserved for Oracle-supplied user accounts. Regular user schemas should refrain from using these tablespaces to avoid a possible denial of service caused by exhausting these resources.

items.summary: Found 4 user accounts that require removal of older password versions.  No user accounts have HTTP verifiers.
items.title: Legacy Password Versions
items.oneline: User accounts should not have legacy password versions
items.details:
Database supports password versions up to 12C.
Users authenticated using the legacy password versions: (none)
Users with latest 12C password version and legacy password versions: HR(11G 12C), PDBADMIN(11G 12C), SH(11G 12C), SYSTEM(11G 12C)

Users with HTTP verifiers: (none)
items.remarks:
The database may store multiple password versions for each user account, where each version supports a different version of the password hashing algorithm. Every user account should include a version for the latest password version supported by the database so that the user can be authenticated using the latest algorithm supported by the client. When all clients have been updated, the security of user accounts can be improved by removing obsolete versions. 

HTTP password verifiers are used  for XML Database authentication. Use the ALTER USER command to remove these verifiers from user accounts that do not require this access.

Common users cannot be altered in a PDB.

items.summary: Found 4 users not governed by a password verification function.
items.title: Users with no Password Complexity Requirements
items.oneline: Ensure password verify function is set in user profiles
items.details:
Profiles with password verification function: ORA_CIS_PROFILE (ORA12C_VERIFY_FUNCTION), ORA_STIG_PROFILE (ORA12C_STIG_VERIFY_FUNCTION)
Profiles without password verification function: DEFAULT
Users without password verification function: HR, PDBADMIN, SH, SYSTEM
items.remarks:
Password verification functions enforce minimum password complexity standards, including length, use of special characters, uniqueness from previous passwords, etc. Oracle provides predefined functions that can be used, or a custom PL/SQL function can be developed. Every user profile should include a password verification function.

Common users cannot be altered in a PDB.

items.summary: User accounts are configured to prevent brute force password attacks by locking the account after a number of failed login attempts. User accounts are configured to stay locked for a minimum duration after being locked due to failed login attempts.
items.title: Account Locking after Failed Login Attempts
items.oneline: Lock the account after limited number of failed login attempts
items.details:
FAILED_LOGIN_ATTEMPTS:
Profiles with limited failed login attempts: DEFAULT (10), ORA_CIS_PROFILE (5), ORA_STIG_PROFILE (3)
Profiles with unlimited failed login attempts: (none)
Users with unlimited failed login attempts: (none)

PASSWORD_LOCK_TIME:
Profiles with minimum lock time: DEFAULT (1 day), ORA_CIS_PROFILE (1 day)
Profiles without minimum lock time: ORA_STIG_PROFILE
Users without minimum lock time: (none)
items.remarks: Setting FAILED_LOGIN_ATTEMPTS and PASSWORD_LOCK_TIME in user profiles is recommended to defend against password-guessing attacks. This will lock the account after a certain number of failed login attempts for a certain time. To expedite the identification and prompt response, assign temporary users to a profile tailored to their type of activity.

items.summary: Password lifetime is set for all users. Found 4 users with no limits on password reuse. Found 4 users with no minimum time before password reuse. All user accounts lock after password expiration.
items.title: Users with Unlimited Password Lifetime
items.oneline: Disallow using the same password indefinitely
items.details:
PASSWORD_LIFE_TIME:
Profiles with limited password lifetime: DEFAULT (180 days), ORA_CIS_PROFILE (90 days), ORA_STIG_PROFILE (35 days)
Profiles with unlimited password lifetime: (none)
Users with unlimited password lifetime: (none)

PASSWORD_REUSE_MAX:
Profiles with limits on password reuse: ORA_CIS_PROFILE (20 times), ORA_STIG_PROFILE (5 times)
Profiles without limits on password reuse: DEFAULT
Users without limits on password reuse: HR, PDBADMIN, SH, SYSTEM

PASSWORD_REUSE_TIME:
Profiles with minimum time before password reuse: ORA_CIS_PROFILE (365 days), ORA_STIG_PROFILE (175 days)
Profiles without minimum time before password reuse: DEFAULT
Users without minimum time before password reuse: HR, PDBADMIN, SH, SYSTEM

PASSWORD_GRACE_TIME:
Profiles with locking after password expiration: DEFAULT (7 days), ORA_CIS_PROFILE (5 days), ORA_STIG_PROFILE (0 day)
Profiles without locking after password expiration: (none)
Users without locking after password expiration: (none)
items.remarks:
Password expiration ensures that users change their passwords regularly. It also provides a mechanism to disable temporary accounts automatically. Passwords that never expire may remain unchanged for an extended period. When passwords do not have to be changed regularly, users are more likely to use the same passwords for multiple accounts.

Common users cannot be altered in a PDB.

items.summary: Found 1 user with the ability to create unlimited concurrent sessions.
items.title: Users with Unlimited Concurrent Sessions
items.oneline: Control the users who can have unlimited concurrent user sessions
items.details:
SESSIONS_PER_USER:
Profiles with limited concurrent sessions: ORA_CIS_PROFILE (10)
Profiles without limited concurrent sessions: DEFAULT, ORA_STIG_PROFILE
Users with unlimited concurrent sessions: PDBADMIN
items.remarks: The SESSIONS_PER_USER parameter determines the maximum number of concurrent sessions a user can create. A user's ability to create unlimited sessions may result in memory resource exhaustion or Denial-of-Service attacks.

items.summary: Found 1 user that can remain connected to the database indefinitely without having their sessions terminated due to inactivity.
items.title: Users with Unlimited Session Idle Time
items.oneline: User sessions should not be idle indefinitely
items.details:
IDLE_TIME:
Profiles with limited IDLE_TIME: ORA_STIG_PROFILE (15)
Profiles with unlimited IDLE_TIME: DEFAULT, ORA_CIS_PROFILE
Users with unlimited IDLE_TIME: PDBADMIN
items.remarks: Sessions left open while users are absent can lead to unauthorized sensitive data access without having attackers worry about subverting privileges or breaking passwords to get access. Controlling the session's idle time is more relevant to client-server applications or terminal connections. The IDLE_TIME parameter in user profiles specifies the permitted duration of continuous inactive time during a session, after which the session is terminated.

items.summary: No profiles found with PASSWORD_ROLLOVER_TIME set to a value greater than 0.
items.title: Users with Gradual Password Rollover
items.oneline: Disallow using both old and new passwords indefinitely when in password rollover
items.remarks: Gradual Password Rollover allows administrators to change application database passwords without having to schedule downtime. Before the gradual password rollover feature, the database administrator needed to take the application down while the database password was being rotated. This was because the password update required changes on both the database and the application side. With gradual database password rollover, the application can continue to use the older password until the new password is configured in the application. To accomplish this, the database administrator can associate a profile having a non-zero limit for the PASSWORD_ROLLOVER_TIME password profile parameter with an application schema. This allows the database password of the application user to be altered while allowing the older password to remain valid for the time specified by the PASSWORD_ROLLOVER_TIME limit. Try to limit the use of this feature to application schemas that need to undergo password maintenance and keep the rollover period to a minimum.

items.summary: No users found with unlimited INACTIVE_ACCOUNT_TIME or unlimited PASSWORD_LIFE_TIME.
items.title: Temporary Users
items.oneline: Temporary accounts should be locked or dropped
items.remarks: User accounts that are not accessed for a while and stay OPEN may not be needed on a regular basis and may have been created for temporary activities. Users designated as temporary or emergency accounts shall automatically be locked after an organization-defined period. Giving these users a tailored temporary profile that sets limits for this particular type of account helps reduce the risk of account misuse. You should review locked accounts periodically to assess if you can drop them.

items.summary: It is recommended to restrict developers from modifying the production database structure or altering production data.
items.title: Development Users in Production Databases
items.oneline: Disallow developer user accounts in production databases
items.remarks: The database must be protected from unauthorized access by developers, and developer-type accounts should not exist in production systems unless expressly authorized. These users should not be able to create and maintain tables or other database objects. If necessary, provide developers with specific tablespaces and don't grant quota on tablespaces owning production objects. Database Vault can help establish trusted paths between applications and the database to help prevent developers from connecting from non-sanctioned servers/clients to the database.

items.summary: Minimum client version is not configured correctly.
items.title: Minimum Client Authentication Version
items.oneline: Update clients using old password versions
items.details:
SQLNET.ALLOWED_LOGON_VERSION_SERVER is not set (default value = 12). Recommended value is 12a.
SQLNET.ALLOWED_LOGON_VERSION_CLIENT is not set (default value = 11). Recommended value is 12a.
items.remarks: Over time, Oracle releases have added support for increasingly secure versions of the algorithm used for password authentication of user accounts. For backward client compatibility, the database keeps supporting previous password versions. The sqlnet.ora parameter ALLOWED_LOGON_VERSION_SERVER determines the minimum password version that the database will accept. Set this parameter to the highest value supported by the database for maximum security once all client systems have been upgraded. Consider evaluating before setting ALLOWED_LOGON_VERSION_SERVER to 12a as it may prevent older clients from connecting to the database instance.

items.summary:
No user granted read on dictionary tables containing password verifiers.
 Verified that no grants have been made to PUBLIC.
No user granted write on dictionary tables containing password verifiers.
 Verified that no grants have been made to PUBLIC.
items.title: Access to Password Verifier Tables
items.oneline: Disallow access to password verifiers in dictionary tables
items.remarks: Users with READ, SELECT, and UPDATE privileges on dictionary tables containing verifiers can access and modify user password verifiers. The verifiers can be used in offline attacks to discover user passwords.

items.summary: Found 2 users granted administrative SYS* privileges. Found 3  administrative SYS* privileges not granted to any user.
items.title: Users with Administrative SYS* Privileges
items.oneline: Segregate administrative privileges among different user accounts
items.details:
SYSDBA    (2): SYS, SYSTEM
SYSOPER   (1): SYS
SYSBACKUP (0): (none)
SYSDG     (0): (none)
SYSKM     (0): (none)
items.remarks: Administrative SYS* privileges allow a user to perform maintenance operations, including some that may occur while the database is not open. The SYSDBA privilege allows the user to run as SYS and perform virtually all privileged operations. Starting with Oracle Database 12.1, Oracle introduced less powerful administrative privileges to allow users to perform specific administrative tasks with less than full SYSDBA privileges. To benefit from this separation of duty, you should grant each of these administrative privileges to at least one named user account.

items.summary:
2 out of 33 users have been directly or indirectly granted DBA/PDB_DBA role via 2 grants.
 1 user is granted DBA/PDB_DBA role with admin option via 1 grant.
No Objects owned by DBA(s) can be accessed by non-DBA(s).
items.title: Users with DBA Role
items.oneline: Ensure DBA and PDB_DBA roles are granted only to necessary users
items.details:
Users with highly sensitive DBA/PDB_DBA role:

PDBADMIN: PDB_DBA(*)

SYSTEM: DBA

(*) = granted with admin option
items.remarks:
The DBA and PDB_DBA roles are powerful and can bypass many security controls. You should only grant them to a small number of trusted administrators. As a best practice, it is recommended to create custom DBA-like roles with the minimum set of privileges that users require to execute their tasks (least privilege principle) and not grant the DBA or PDB_DBA roles. Privilege Analysis can assist in identifying used/unused privileges and roles. Different roles with minimum required privileges based on the types of operations database administrators execute also help achieve Separation of Duties.

Furthermore, each trusted user should have an individual account for accountability reasons. You should audit users with the DBA or PDB_DBA roles to detect unauthorized privileged activity. Avoid granting the DBA, PDB_DBA, or custom DBA-like powerful roles with WITH ADMIN option unless necessary. Please note that Oracle may add or remove roles and privileges from the DBA or PDB_DBA role.

Commonly granted DBA role cannot be revoked in a PDB.

7 out of 33 users have been directly or indirectly granted powerful roles via 37 grants.
 1 user is granted powerful roles with admin option via 1 grant.

items.oneline: User accounts with catalog roles should be limited
items.details:
Grants of AQ_ADMINISTRATOR_ROLE, EM_EXPRESS_ALL, EXP_FULL_DATABASE, IMP_FULL_DATABASE, SELECT_CATALOG_ROLE, EXECUTE_CATALOG_ROLE, DELETE_CATALOG_ROLE, OEM_MONITOR, DBA, AUDIT_ADMIN roles:

GSMUSER <- GSMUSER_ROLE <- DATAPUMP_EXP_FULL_DATABASE <- EXP_FULL_DATABASE: EXECUTE_CATALOG_ROLE, SELECT_CATALOG_ROLE

SYSTEM: AQ_ADMINISTRATOR_ROLE(*), DBA
SYSTEM <- DBA: EXECUTE_CATALOG_ROLE, EXP_FULL_DATABASE, IMP_FULL_DATABASE, SELECT_CATALOG_ROLE
SYSTEM <- DBA <- DATAPUMP_EXP_FULL_DATABASE: EXP_FULL_DATABASE
SYSTEM <- DBA <- DATAPUMP_EXP_FULL_DATABASE <- EXP_FULL_DATABASE: EXECUTE_CATALOG_ROLE, SELECT_CATALOG_ROLE
SYSTEM <- DBA <- DATAPUMP_IMP_FULL_DATABASE: EXP_FULL_DATABASE, IMP_FULL_DATABASE
SYSTEM <- DBA <- DATAPUMP_IMP_FULL_DATABASE <- EXP_FULL_DATABASE: EXECUTE_CATALOG_ROLE, SELECT_CATALOG_ROLE
SYSTEM <- DBA <- DATAPUMP_IMP_FULL_DATABASE <- IMP_FULL_DATABASE: EXECUTE_CATALOG_ROLE, SELECT_CATALOG_ROLE

SYSTEM <- DBA <- IMP_FULL_DATABASE: EXECUTE_CATALOG_ROLE, SELECT_CATALOG_ROLE

(*) = granted with admin option
items.remarks:
DBA and other similarly powerful roles (AQ_ADMINISTRATOR_ROLE, EM_EXPRESS_ALL, EXP_FULL_DATABASE, IMP_FULL_DATABASE, SELECT_CATALOG_ROLE, EXECUTE_CATALOG_ROLE, DELETE_CATALOG_ROLE, OEM_MONITOR, DBA, AUDIT_ADMIN) contain powerful privileges that attackers can use to bypass security controls. They should be granted only to a small number of trusted administrators. You should revoke the grant of these roles with the WITH ADMIN OPTION from unauthorized grantees. Auditing users with these roles is recommended to detect any unauthorized activity. Use Privilege Analysis to identify if the users used these privileges. If not, consider revoking.

Commonly granted above powerful roles cannot be revoked in a PDB.

items.remarks:
System privileges provide the ability to access data or perform administrative operations for the entire database, and users granted system privileges are generally used to perform administrative work. Consistent with the principle of least privilege, you should grant these privileges sparingly. Privilege Analysis may help determine the minimum set of privileges required by a user or a role. In some cases, it may be possible to substitute a more limited object privilege grant instead of a system privilege (ANY) grant that applies to all objects.

Avoid granting system privileges with ADMIN OPTION. You should review users with system privileges to determine if they are used to perform administrative and general user responsibilities. You should provide users with administrative and general user responsibilities with separate accounts for each duty.

Commonly granted system privileges cannot be revoked in a PDB.

items.title: System Privileges Granted to PUBLIC
items.oneline: PUBLIC role should not have system privileges
items.remarks: Privileges granted to PUBLIC are available to all users. This generally should include few, if any, system privileges since these will not be needed by ordinary users who are not administrators.

items.summary: No roles granted to PUBLIC.
items.title: Roles Granted to PUBLIC
items.oneline: PUBLIC role should not have any unnecessary roles granted
items.remarks:
Roles granted to PUBLIC are available to all users. Roles might contain privileges that are not appropriate for all users. You can use Privilege Analysis to identify if users/applications used these privileges and, if not, revoke them.

If this database supports a packaged application, work with the application provider and Oracle support to understand to what extent you can revoke role grants made to PUBLIC.

items.summary: Verified that no column privileges have been granted to PUBLIC.
items.title: Column Privileges Granted to PUBLIC
items.oneline: Disallow unnecessary column privilege grants to PUBLIC
items.remarks: Privileges granted to PUBLIC are available to all users. Avoid granting column privileges to PUBLIC, as that data will become accessible to everyone.

items.summary: No object grants to PUBLIC.
items.title: Objects Accessible by PUBLIC
items.oneline: Disallow unnecessary object privileges granted to PUBLIC
items.remarks:
Object grants to PUBLIC must be avoided and should be removed using the REVOKE command.

If this database supports a package application, work with the application provider and Oracle support to understand to what extent you can revoke role grants made to PUBLIC.

items.summary: The EXECUTE privilege on 1 encryption package is granted to PUBLIC.
items.title: Encryption Packages Granted to PUBLIC
items.oneline: Control EXECUTE grants on encryption packages to PUBLIC
items.details: EXECUTE privilege to PUBLIC granted on: DBMS_RANDOM
items.remarks:
Privileges granted to PUBLIC are available to all users. EXECUTE privilege on encryption-related packages allows, among other things, encrypting and decrypting stored data. If a database user needs to execute an encryption-related package, explicitly grant the privilege to the user instead of granting it to PUBLIC.

EXECUTE privilege grant on DBMS_CRYPTO and DBMS_RANDOM packages to PUBLIC should be reviewed, per your organizational security requirements. If you encrypt your data using DBMS_CRYPTO, ensure that you securely manage the encryption keys, including its lifecycle and confidentiality.

DBMS_RANDOM generates a predictable set of random values and should not be used for cryptographic purposes.

items.summary: The EXECUTE privilege on 2 Job Scheduler packages is granted to PUBLIC. Found 5 users with system privilege to create a job without explicit EXECUTE on job packages but uses EXECUTE granted to PUBLIC.
items.title: Scheduler Job Packages Granted to PUBLIC
items.oneline: Control EXECUTE grants on job scheduler packages to PUBLIC
items.details:
EXECUTE privilege to PUBLIC granted on: DBMS_SCHEDULER, DBMS_JOB
Found 5 Users who can create jobs without explicit EXECUTE privileges on job packages: DBSNMP, XDB, CTXSYS, GSMADMIN_INTERNAL, SYSTEM(*)
1 user can create external scheduler jobs without explicit EXECUTE privilege: SYSTEM(*)
3 users who can create scheduler jobs within other schemas without explicit EXECUTE privilege: CTXSYS, GSMADMIN_INTERNAL, SYSTEM(*)
5 users who can create scheduler jobs whenever they want without explicit EXECUTE privilege: AUDSYS, DBSNMP, MDSYS, SYSTEM(*), XDB
3 users who can create scheduler jobs whenever they want without explicit EXECUTE privilege: CTXSYS, GSMADMIN_INTERNAL, SYSTEM(*)

(*) = granted with admin option
items.remarks:
Privileges granted to PUBLIC are available to all users. EXECUTE privileges on Job Scheduler packages to PUBLIC allows users with system privileges (CREATE EXTERNAL JOB, CREATE ANY JOB, CREATE JOB, MANAGE SCHEDULER) to run database or operating system jobs without explicit EXECUTE privileges to run these packages. Review users with these system privileges and grant them the appropriate ones. 

Please consider that a user with CREATE EXTERNAL JOB system privilege can run operating system commands outside of the database context; users with CREATE ANY JOB can run database jobs as other users and impersonate them; users with CREATE JOB can execute scripts (or SQL commands) whenever they want. 

While you can REVOKE from PUBLIC and explicitly grant EXECUTE privilege on these packages (DBMS_SCHEDULER, DBMS_JOB) to specific users who need access, it's unnecessary as users will still need to have a system privilege (CREATE EXTERNAL JOB, CREATE ANY JOB, CREATE JOB, MANAGE SCHEDULER) grant to be able to execute jobs. 

Oracle strongly recommends that you switch from DBMS_JOB to DBMS_SCHEDULER scheduled jobs.

items.summary: The EXECUTE privilege on credential package is granted to PUBLIC. Found 2 users granted CREATE CREDENTIAL or CREATE ANY CREDENTIAL system privilege without explicit EXECUTE on DBMS_CREDENTIAL granted but uses the EXECUTE on DBMS_CREDENTIAL granted to PUBLIC.

items.oneline: Control EXECUTE grants on credential package to PUBLIC
items.details:
EXECUTE privilege to PUBLIC granted on: DBMS_CREDENTIAL
2 users granted CREATE CREDENTIAL or CREATE ANY CREDENTIAL privilege who can use EXECUTE on PUBLIC to execute DBMS_CREDENTIAL: GSMADMIN_INTERNAL, SYSTEM(*)

(*) = granted with admin option
items.remarks: Privileges granted to PUBLIC are available to all users. Credentials are database objects that hold a username/password pair for authenticating and impersonating EXTPROC callout functions, remote jobs, external jobs, and file watchers from the SCHEDULER. EXECUTE privilege on DBMS_CREDENTIAL package to PUBLIC allows users with system privileges (CREATE CREDENTIAL, CREATE ANY CREDENTIAL) to manage credentials. Review users with these system privileges and grant them the appropriate ones. While you can REVOKE from PUBLIC and explicitly grant EXECUTE privilege on DBMS_CREDENTIAL to specific users who need access, it's unnecessary as users will still need to have a system privilege (CREATE CREDENTIAL or CREATE ANY CREDENTIAL) grant to be able to manage credentials.

items.title: File System Packages Granted to PUBLIC
items.oneline: Control EXECUTE grants on file system packages to PUBLIC
items.details:
EXECUTE privilege to PUBLIC granted on: DBMS_LOB, UTL_FILE, DBMS_ADVISOR
3 users granted ADVISOR privilege who can use EXECUTE on PUBLIC to execute DBMS_ADVISOR: SYSTEM, DBSNMP, SYS$UMF
4 users granted CREATE ANY DIRECTORY or DROP ANY DIRECTORY system privilege or READ or WRITE object privilege who can use EXECUTE on PUBLIC to execute DBMS_LOB: SYSTEM, GSMUSER, GSMADMIN_INTERNAL, SYSBACKUP
4 users granted CREATE ANY DIRECTORY or DROP ANY DIRECTORY system privilege or READ or WRITE object privilege who can use EXECUTE on PUBLIC to execute UTL_FILE: SYSTEM, GSMUSER, GSMADMIN_INTERNAL, SYSBACKUP
items.remarks:
Privileges granted to PUBLIC are available to all users. Granting EXECUTE privilege on file system packages to PUBLIC could allow users with system privileges (ADVISOR, CREATE ANY DIRECTORY, READ ANY DIRECTORY) or object privileges (READ or WRITE) to modify operating system files without having explicit EXECUTE privileges to run these packages. Review users with these different system and object privileges and grant them the appropriate ones.

While you can REVOKE from PUBLIC and explicitly grant EXECUTE privilege on these packages (DBMS_ADVISOR, DBMS_LOB, UTL_FILE) to specific users who need access, it's unnecessary as users will still need to have a system privilege (ADVISOR, CREATE ANY DIRECTORY, READ ANY DIRECTORY) or an object privilege (READ or WRITE) on DIRECTORY to be able to modify operating system files. Also, DBMS_LOB can be used to manipulate LOBs that are in the database. Please review the users who are authorized to execute DBMS_LOB.

items.summary: The EXECUTE privilege on 5 network packages is granted to PUBLIC. Found 1 user granted network privilege via network ACLs without explicit EXECUTE on network packages but uses EXECUTE granted to PUBLIC.
items.title: Network Packages Granted to PUBLIC
items.oneline: Control EXECUTE grants on network packages to PUBLIC
items.details:
EXECUTE privilege to PUBLIC granted on: DBMS_LDAP, UTL_HTTP, UTL_INADDR, UTL_SMTP, UTL_TCP
1 user granted network privileges via network ACLs who can use EXECUTE on network packages granted to PUBLIC: GSMADMIN_INTERNAL
items.remarks:
Privileges granted to PUBLIC are available to all users. Network packages provide PL/SQL APIs to interact with or access remote servers. Granting EXECUTE privilege on network packages to PUBLIC does not allow an unauthorized user or attacker to connect to a remote server and exfiltrate data. If a database user needs to move data through the network packages, the user will need to be authorized via an ACL using DBMS_NETWORK_ACL_ADMIN and DBMS_NETWORK_ACL_UTILITY packages.

DBMS_LDAP requires authentication prior to using other functions.

Oracle best practice is to control the use of packages and to NOT revoke the grants from PUBLIC.

items.summary: The EXECUTE privilege on 1 Java package is granted to PUBLIC. Found 1 user is granted JAVA_ADMIN to administer Java permissions without direct EXECUTE on Java packages but uses EXECUTE privilege granted to PUBLIC.
items.title: JAVA Packages Granted to PUBLIC
items.oneline: Control EXECUTE grants on Java packages to PUBLIC
items.details:
EXECUTE privilege to PUBLIC granted on: DBMS_JAVA
1 user is granted JAVA_ADMIN role and can administer Java policies without direct EXECUTE privilege on Java packages: SYSTEM
items.remarks:
EXECUTE privilege on Java packages (DBMS_JAVA, DBMS_JAVA_TEST) could allow an attacker to run operating system commands from the database. Only JAVA_ADMIN users can grant permission to other users to access various Java classes. EXECUTE privilege to PUBLIC allows users to administer Java policies without explicit privileges to run these packages. 

You should review EXECUTE privilege on Java packages granted to PUBLIC per your organizational standard to prevent an unauthorized user from using Java function. Additionally, the JAVA_ADMIN role should be granted only to authorized users.

items.summary: The EXECUTE privilege on 5 packages that take SQL query as input is granted to PUBLIC.
items.title: SQL Packages Granted to PUBLIC
items.oneline: Control EXECUTE grants on packages that allows SQL as input to PUBLIC
items.details: EXECUTE privilege to PUBLIC granted on: DBMS_XMLQUERY, DBMS_XMLSAVE, DBMS_XMLSTORE, DBMS_XMLGEN, DBMS_SQL
items.remarks:
Privileges granted to PUBLIC are available to all users. EXECUTE privilege on packages that allow SQL execution or DML operations could allow an attacker to inject malicious SQL in vulnerable PL/SQL procedures - and perform a SQL injection attack - which could lead to sensitive data exposure. 

While you can REVOKE from PUBLIC and explicitly grant EXECUTE privilege on these invokers' rights packages (DBMS_SQL, DBMS_REDACT, DBMS_XMLGEN, DBMS_XMLQUERY, DBMS_XMLSAVE, DBMS_XMLSTORE) to specific users who need access, it is more effective to review PL/SQL code and ensure the use of bind variables instead of concatenating SQL statements with strings. When SQL statements employ string concatenation, they become vulnerable to potential SQL injection attacks through malicious inputs.

items.remarks: Users with broad data access privileges (SELECT ANY TABLE, READ ANY TABLE, INSERT ANY TABLE, DELETE ANY TABLE, ALTER ANY TABLE, UPDATE ANY TABLE, CREATE ANY TRIGGER, ALTER ANY TRIGGER, CREATE ANY INDEX, CREATE ANY PROCEDURE, SELECT ANY DICTIONARY, EXECUTE ANY PROCEDURE) have access to data stored in any schema. Most administrative tasks do not require access to the data itself, so you should grant these privileges rarely, even to administrators. Users with direct object privileges on tables that hold sensitive data should also be reviewed. In addition to minimizing grants of these privileges, consider using Database Vault realms to limit the use of these privileges to access sensitive data stored in user schemas. Privilege Analysis may help you identify the underlying objects being accessed via the broad privilege and help you substitute it with a more limited object privilege grant. You should avoid granting broad data access system privileges with ADMIN option, as the recipient will be able to grant the privilege further.

SELECT_CATALOG_ROLE: DBSNMP, GSMADMIN_INTERNAL, GSMUSER, SYSBACKUP, SYSTEM
SYSUMF_ROLE: SYS$UMF
WM_ADMIN_ROLE: PDBADMIN, SYSTEM, WMSYS
XDBADMIN: GSMCATUSER, SYSTEM
XDB_SET_INVOKER: SYSTEM
items.remarks:
Roles offer a convenient way to manage groups of associated privileges, especially when these privileges are needed for a particular job function or task. However, you should take caution with overly broadly defined roles as they may grant excessive privileges to the recipient. Privilege Analysis can help identify the exact privileges required by the users and ensure the least privileges. You should only grant roles with ADMIN option if the recipient requires the capability to modify the role or grant it further.

Commonly granted roles cannot be revoked in a PDB.

items.remarks:
Account management privileges (ALTER USER, CREATE USER, DROP USER) can be used to create and modify other user accounts, including changing passwords. Attackers can abuse this ability to gain access to another user's account, which may have greater privileges. You should audit users with Account management privileges.

Commonly granted account management privileges cannot be revoked in a PDB.

This could undermine database security controls. Privilege Analysis may help determine whether a user or role has used privilege management privileges. If you have identified users that should not have these privileges, revoke them.

Commonly granted role and privilege management privileges cannot be revoked in a PDB.

Database management privileges (ALTER DATABASE, ALTER SYSTEM, CREATE ANY LIBRARY, CREATE LIBRARY, DROP ANY LIBRARY) can be used to change the operation of the database and potentially bypass security protections. CREATE LIBRARY allows a user to create or replace a library. This ability should be granted only to trusted administrators and should be audited.

Commonly granted Database management privileges cannot be revoked in a PDB.

The DBMS_AUDIT_MGMT package is used to execute Audit Trail management procedures and functions. Users with the EXECUTE privilege on the package can invoke subprograms like CLEAN_AUDIT_TRAIL that purges audit trail records or archived files. Access should be strictly limited and granted only to users with a legitimate need for this functionality.

Commonly granted EXECUTE on Audit management packages cannot be revoked in a PDB.

items.remarks:
Audit management privileges (AUDIT ANY, AUDIT SYSTEM) can be used to add, drop and modify the audit policies for the database. You should only grant these privileges to highly trusted administrators since they may be abused to hide malicious activity. Privilege Analysis may help determine whether a user or role has used the audit management privileges. You should audit users with these privileges.

Commonly granted Audit management privileges cannot be revoked in a PDB.

items.title: Access to Audit Objects
items.oneline: Disallow privileges for modification of database audit data
items.details:
Grants of SELECT, DELETE, INSERT, UPDATE on AUDIT objects:

DBSNMP <- DV_MONITOR: SELECT on DVSYS.AUDIT_TRAIL$
items.remarks:
Users with these privileges can directly access and modify objects containing audit information. Access to audit data may allow a malicious user to deduce privilege settings for other users and manipulate the audit information by replacing or deleting audit records. Use Privilege Analysis to identify used and unused access to these privileges. Instead of granting a default role with many privileges, such as DBA or SELECT_CATALOG_ROLE, create custom roles that only contain the necessary system and object privileges the user or role needs to perform the task.

Commonly granted object privileges on audit objects cannot be revoked in a PDB.

items.remarks:
Users with access control exemption privileges (EXEMPT ACCESS POLICY, EXEMPT REDACTION POLICY) can bypass the row and column access control policies enforced by Virtual Private Database and Data Redaction. Most administrative tasks do not require access to the data itself, so you should grant these privileges rarely, even to administrators. You should audit users with these privileges.

Commonly granted access control exemption privileges cannot be revoked in a PDB.

items.remarks:
Users with these privileges can directly modify objects in the SYS, DVSYS, AUDSYS, or LBACSYS schemas. Manipulating these system objects may allow security protections to be circumvented or otherwise interfere with the normal operation of the database. You should not grant access to objects in SYS, DVSYS, AUDSYS, and LBACSYS schemas to PUBLIC. When running a Privilege Analysis Capture, be aware of privileges granted to access objects in any Oracle-created schemas. Review those privilege grants for relevance.

Commonly granted write privileges on SYS, DVSYS, AUDSYS or LBACSYS objects cannot be revoked in a PDB.

items.remarks:
The BECOME USER privilege and some PL/SQL packages (DBMS_AQADM_SYS, DBMS_AQADM_SYSCALLS, DBMS_IJOB, DBMS_PRVTAQIM, DBMS_REPCAT_SQL_UTL, DBMS_STREAMS_ADM_UTL, DBMS_STREAMS_RPC, DBMS_SYS_SQL, INITJVMAUX, LTADM, WWV_DBMS_SQL, WWV_EXECUTE_IMMEDIATE) allow the execution of SQL code or external jobs using the identity of a different user. Access should be strictly limited and granted only to users with a legitimate need for this functionality. Use Privilege Analysis to identify used and unused access to these privileges. Users with BECOME USER privilege and EXECUTE privilege on the above packages should be audited.

Commonly granted BECOME USER privilege cannot be revoked in a PDB.

You should grant access only to users with a legitimate need for this functionality. Use Privilege Analysis to identify if these privileges were used. If not, consider revoking.

Commonly granted EXECUTE privilege on these packages cannot be revoked in a PDB.

items.remarks: You can use Code Based Access Control (CBAC) to grant additional privileges on program units like PL/SQL functions, procedures, or packages. CBAC allows you to grant database roles to a PL/SQL function, procedure, or package. These database roles are enabled at run time, allowing the program unit to execute with the required privileges in the calling user's environment.

items.remarks:
Java permission grants control over the ability of database users to execute Java classes within the database server. A database user executing Java code must have both Java security permissions and database privileges to access resources within the database. These resources include database resources, such as tables and PL/SQL packages; operating system resources, such as files and sockets; Oracle JVM classes and user-loaded classes. Make sure that these permissions are limited to the minimum required by each user. Use Privilege Analysis to identify if these privileges were used. If not, consider revoking.

Commonly granted Java permissions cannot be revoked in a PDB.

items.summary: Database Vault is not enabled.
items.title: Database Vault
items.oneline: Ensure separation of duties and limit sensitive data access
items.remarks: Database Vault offers customizable policies to regulate the actions of privileged database accounts, such as those used by administrative users, applications, and utilities. Internal and external threats can exploit privileged account credentials to access sensitive information. Database Vault realms protect sensitive data from unauthorized access, even by users with system privileges. Command rules in Database Vault limit accidental or malicious execution of SQL commands. You can enforce separation of duties to prevent a single all-powerful user and use trusted paths to restrict further access to sensitive data based on system factors such as IP address, program name, time of day, and user name. Database Vault Operations Control can be used to restrict common users from accessing data local to pluggable databases (PDB). Database Vault Operations Control can be used to restrict common users from accessing pluggable database (PDB) local data in autonomous, regular Cloud or on-premises environments.

items.summary: Privilege Analysis policies not found. Privilege Analysis has never been run.
items.title: Privilege Analysis
items.oneline: Implement the principle of least privilege
items.details: Users who can start the privilege analysis capture process: SYSTEM
items.remarks: Privilege Analysis dynamically analyzes privilege and role usage in real time, providing insight into actual use by database users and application service accounts. This feature helps strengthen security by identifying unused or redundant privileges and roles, allowing administrators to determine the minimum privileges required for users or applications to function correctly. Administrators can confidently revoke unnecessary privileges with clear visibility into assigned privileges and their usage. Privilege Analysis helps implement the least privilege model and minimize the risk of intentional or accidental abuse of privileges.

items.summary: Found 5 password-authenticated users whose passwords can potentially be embedded in client scripts, jobs, and application source code to connect to the database server.
items.title: Authentication for Client Scripts
items.oneline: Check user account passwords within scripts and batch jobs
items.details: Users with a password that can be embedded in client scripts: HR, PDBADMIN, SH, SYS, SYSTEM
items.remarks: Typically, users (including applications, batch jobs, and scripts) connect to databases using a standard CONNECT statement specifying a database connection string. This string often includes the username and password in clear text. Embedding credentials (hardcoded credentials) into source code is highly discouraged. It poses significant security risks and makes it harder to comply with password expiration and rotation mandates. A better alternative is to use Oracle Key Vault (OKV) or a Secure External Password Store (SEPS), so application users, batch jobs, and scripts can connect to the database without having the password written in the code. With OKV, an authorized client can fetch a database user password in real time and connect to the database without storing the password. With SEPS, the database credentials, username, and password are securely stored in an Oracle Keystore created for this purpose. It is essential to thoroughly review client code to detect the presence of passwords in clear text. Additionally, applications should employ measures to conceal any authentication information displayed following a successful or unsuccessful connection attempt.

items.summary: No table is marked as containing sensitive data. Found 3 users who can transfer sensitive data.
items.title: Data Masking
items.oneline: Anonymize sensitive data in non-production environments
items.details: Users that can transfer sensitive data: SYSTEM, GSMUSER, GSMADMIN_INTERNAL
items.remarks: Clones of live production data are typically shared with development, testing, and data analytics teams so that they have access to realistic data to support their activities. Attackers have learned that valuable and sensitive data often ends up in non-production environments, which are generally less protected than production. Masking sensitive data before handing it over to development and analytics teams eliminates the risk of data breaches in non-production environments by irreversibly replacing the original sensitive data with realistic but fictitious data. Procedures that ensure copies of production data are kept away from non-secured locations must also be in place. Oracle Data Safe or Oracle Data Masking and Subsetting Pack can help you anonymize sensitive data transferred to non-production systems.

items.summary: Externally authenticated users do not exist.
items.title: PKI-based Authentication
items.oneline: Use PKI-based authentication for STIG compliance
items.remarks: If you follow the STIG compliance standards, ensure that accounts used by processes to connect to the database are authenticated using valid and current Department of Defense (DoD) issued PKI certificates. If this is the case, then this is not a finding. Processes or devices that connect to the database using externally authenticated accounts should use PKI-based authentication.

items.summary: No data redaction policies found.
items.title: Data Redaction
items.oneline: Redact sensitive data for read-only application screens
items.details:
Users exempted from Data Redaction Policies: GSMADMIN_INTERNAL, GSMUSER, SYSTEM
Users who can create or manage Data Redaction Policies: GSMADMIN_INTERNAL, GSMUSER, SYSTEM
items.remarks: Data Redaction automatically masks sensitive data found in the results of a database query. The data is dynamically masked before it is returned as part of the result set, so it does not interfere with any conditions specified as part of the query. Data Redaction is mainly used to redact data in read-only scenarios (e.g., read-only screens, REST GET APIs). The redaction policy will not affect access by users with the EXEMPT REDACTION POLICY privilege. Users who can execute the DBMS_REDACT package can create and modify redaction policies. Also, consider using Oracle Data Safe or Oracle Data Masking and Subsetting Pack to permanently mask sensitive data when making copies for test or development.

items.summary: No VPD policies found that automatically limit access to certain rows and/or columns based upon the user or the database environment.
items.title: Virtual Private Database
items.oneline: Control access to sensitive data at the row level
items.details:
Users exempted from VPD Policies: GSMADMIN_INTERNAL, GSMUSER
Users who can create or manage VPD Policies: GSMADMIN_INTERNAL, GSMUSER, MDSYS, SYSTEM, WMSYS, XDB
items.remarks: Virtual Private Database (VPD) allows for fine-grained control over which rows and columns of a table are visible to a SQL statement. Access control using VPD limits each database session to only the specific data it should be able to access. Access by users with the EXEMPT ACCESS POLICY privilege will not be affected by VPD policies. Users who can execute the DBMS_RLS package can create and modify these policies. Evaluate Real Application Security before implementing VPD, especially for new custom applications.

items.summary: No RAS policies found.
items.title: Real Application Security
items.oneline: Control access to sensitive data at the row and column level
items.details:
Users not impacted by RAS Policies: GSMADMIN_INTERNAL, GSMUSER
Users who can create or manage RAS policies: DBSFWUSER, SYSTEM, SYSTEM
items.remarks: Real Application Security (RAS) is a more modern, advanced version of Virtual Private Database. It provides fine-grained control over the rows and columns of a table that are visible to a SQL statement. RAS data access policies use a declarative syntax based on access control lists. Access by users with the EXEMPT ACCESS POLICY privilege will not be affected by RAS access policies. Users with ADMIN_SEC_POLICY and APPLY_SEC_POLICY privileges can create and modify these policies.

items.summary: Label Security is not enabled.
items.title: Label Security
items.oneline: Classify sensitive data and authorize access using labels
items.remarks:
Oracle Label Security (OLS) provides a framework for implementing and enforcing multi-level security (MLS) policies within a database. MLS is a security model that allows you to classify data into different security levels and assign users different levels of clearance for accessing that data. With OLS, you can define classification labels, associate them with table rows, and then control access to the rows based on the security labels and the user's clearance level. This helps to ensure that sensitive information is protected and only available to authorized users. Access by users with the EXEMPT ACCESS POLICY privilege will not be affected by the Label Security policies. Each policy has a corresponding administrative role; users who have this role can administer the policy.

Starting Oracle Database 23ai, Oracle Label Security cannot be used with Oracle Internet Directory (OID) since Directory Integration Platform is being deprecated. Oracle recommends moving from OLS-OID configuration to stand-alone OLS configuration before upgrading to Oracle Database 23ai.

items.summary: No data tagged with sensitive types found.
items.title: Transparent Sensitive Data Protection (TSDP)
items.oneline: Classify and transparently protect sensitive data
items.details:
Policies: (none)
Users with EXECUTE on SYS.DBMS_TSDP_MANAGE: (none)
Users with EXECUTE on SYS.DBMS_TSDP_PROTECT: (none)
items.remarks: Transparent Sensitive Data Protection (TSDP) allows a sensitive type (such as a Credit Card number) to be associated with each column that contains sensitive data. TSDP policy can apply data security controls such as Data Redaction, auditing, VPD, and even mask bind values (in auditing and trace files) to all instances of that particular type so that protection is uniform and consistent. Users who can execute the DBMS_TSDP_MANAGE and DBMS_TSDP_PROTECT packages can manage sensitive data types and the security controls applied by the TSDP policies.

items.summary: Examined 1 audit trail. Found records in 1 audit trail.
items.title: Audit Records
items.oneline: Ensure Auditing is enabled
items.details: Unified Audit Trail: In use, 13809 records found (Oct 18 2024 - Dec 14 2024)
items.remarks: Auditing plays a crucial role in overseeing the operations of any system, including those performed by highly privileged users. With the introduction of Unified Auditing in Oracle Database 12c, auditing has become more streamlined and secure. This feature consolidates all database sources of audit logs into a single, easily manageable trail and adds powerful conditional auditing capabilities. While the AUDIT_SYSLOG_LEVEL parameter helps send condensed audit records to a remote syslog collector, a more secure and comprehensive approach would be to use Oracle Data Safe or Oracle Audit Vault and Database Firewall. These tools streamline the implementation of a widely recognized best practice and common regulatory requirement, which mandates the transfer of audit data from databases to a separate server while maintaining full audit record details.

items.remarks: The Unified Auditing feature in Oracle Database allows you to capture all audit activity in a single, central location. It also introduces a new syntax for creating more detailed and specific audit policies, enabling you to build conditions and add exclusions. In addition, the database provides a set of pre-defined audit policies that you can use to meet frequent audit requirements. Review enabled and disabled audit policies to ensure you are meeting your auditing requirements. However, care must be taken while configuring audit policies for ALL actions and for ALL users to prevent generation of huge volume of audit trails.

Users with EXECUTE on SYS.DBMS_FGA: GSMADMIN_INTERNAL, GSMUSER, SYSTEM
items.remarks: Fine-Grained Audit (FGA) policies can audit data access based on content. Using FGA policies, you can specify the columns and conditions for which you want to generate audit records. This effectively audits targeted data access while avoiding unnecessary audit records that correspond to regular activity. FGA policies also allow an event handler to be specified. This event handler is a PL/SQL function that, for example, can warn a database administrator of suspicious activity. You should only use FGA policies if a unified audit policy cannot answer the requirements.

items.remarks: It is crucial to audit administrative actions performed by the SYS user. Remember that traditional audit policies do not apply to SYS, and in that case, the AUDIT_SYS_OPERATIONS parameter must be set to record SYS actions to a separate audit trail. With Unified Audit policies, you can monitor the actions of the SYS user and those of other users. Make sure that all your SYS* users' activities are audited.

items.remarks: As a best practice, you should audit successful and unsuccessful connections to the database. Connection auditing is valuable information for forensic analysis. Unsuccessful connection attempts can provide early warning of an attacker's attempt to access the database. Auditing the LOGOFF time helps understand how long the session was active. You should enable auditing for LOGON and LOGOFF actions for all the required users.
