items.remarks: Object auditing in Oracle Database provides an effective way to monitor access and changes to sensitive objects. It can provide a detailed record of who has accessed the object and when. You can use this information to support regulatory compliance and identify suspicious activity and unauthorized access to sensitive data, such as fraud identification or during forensic analysis. This finding shows the list of objects audited by one or more enabled unified audit policies. You should review your identified sensitive objects (e.g., TABLES, PROCEDURES, FUNCTIONS) against this list to ensure they are being audited.

items.summary: Actions related to synonym management are audited for all users.
items.title: Audit Synonym Management Activities
items.oneline: Ensure synonym management activities are audited
items.details:
Unified audit - auditing enabled: CREATE ANY SYNONYM, CREATE PUBLIC SYNONYM, CREATE SYNONYM, DROP PUBLIC SYNONYM, DROP SYNONYM

Unified audit - Policies Used: ORA_DV_SCHEMA_CHANGES
Unified audit - Users audited: ALL USERS
items.remarks:
Actions that affect the management of synonyms should always be audited. It is recommended that CREATE SYNONYM, ALTER SYNONYM, DROP SYNONYM, CREATE ANY SYNONYM, CREATE PUBLIC SYNONYM, ALTER PUBLIC SYNONYM, and DROP PUBLIC SYNONYM events are audited. You should include each action or privilege listed here in at least one enabled audit policy for all users.

Traditional audit is deprecated. Oracle recommends using the pure unified audit mode for Oracle Database 12c Release 2 (12.2) and above.

items.summary: No unified audit policies are using conditions.
items.title: Audit Conditions
items.oneline: Use audit conditions to reduce the number of audit records
items.remarks: Unified Audit enables the specification of a condition that determines whether auditing is performed for an action. If the WHEN clause condition evaluates to TRUE, then auditing occurs; else, it does not. Some security-relevant use cases of conditional auditing include auditing user activity for direct database access (bequeath), activity during non-business hours, access to sensitive data through untrusted paths, and in the absence of a specific parameter value on a SYS_CONTEXT namespace.

items.summary: No shared users found.
items.title: Audit Shared Accounts
items.oneline: Audit shared or proxy user's activity
items.remarks:
Having shared accounts to interact with the database may prevent the application from recording an individual user's identity used to insert/update/read/delete records. Use accounts assigned to individual users where feasible. You should audit shared or proxy users' activity. Configure user accounts, the database and/or the application to provide personal accountability. Activity performed under a shared account must include the end user in the audit log.

Also, you should not have accounts with multiple administrative privileges. You should assign each administrative privilege to one user account for better separation of duties. Uses requiring to execute multiple administrative functions can have specific accounts for each activity type.

items.summary: One or more audit trail is in SYSAUX tablespace. Examined 3 audit trails. Audit tablespace with acceptable free space.
items.title: Audit Storage
items.oneline: Audit trail should be stored on a tablespace of its own
items.details:
STANDARD AUDIT TRAIL is in SYSAUX
UNIFIED AUDIT TRAIL is in SYSAUX
FGA AUDIT TRAIL is in SYSAUX
13809 Records found in Unified Audit Trail from Oct 18 2024 to Dec 14 2024
No audit cleanup job configured to clean audit trails.
items.remarks:
Auditing is the most effective way to record what happens in the database. Auditing tracks the use of privileges, activities of highly privileged users, access to sensitive data, actions performed on database objects, and modifications made to database settings. Auditing can be helpful for forensic investigations in the event of a data breach and to demonstrate regulatory compliance. Database audit trails use the SYSAUX tablespace by default and can fill it up. That can affect other database operations that rely on that tablespace. If the tablespace exhausts, audit record writes will spill over to OS audit files, and a message is written to the ALERT LOG. If the OS file system space also becomes full, audited operations will start to fail.

It is recommended to relocate the audit trail to another tablespace using DBMS_AUDIT_MGMT.SET_AUDIT_TRAIL_LOCATION procedure. Relocating to a dedicated tablespace will improve system performance and eliminate the probability of some other component taking up the free space. You can encrypt the new tablespace. Also, make sure you allocate adequate space. Oracle recommends that you configure a different tablespace for the audit trail. You can encrypt the new tablespace. Also, make sure you allocate adequate space.

items.summary: No audit cleanup job found enabled to cleanup audit trails.
items.title: Audit Trail Cleanup
items.oneline: Ensure old audit records are purged regularly
items.remarks:
User and administrator activities must be audited and monitored to implement corporate security guidelines, ensure regulatory compliance and support forensic investigations. This oversight may result in massive amounts of activity data.

Oracle Audit management package DBMS_AUDIT_MGMT provides procedures to manually clean up the audit trail or create automated cleanup jobs.

items.summary: There are no audit policies to track Data Pump exports. There are no audit policies to track Data Pump imports.
items.title: Audit Data Pump
items.oneline: Data Pump exports and imports should be audited
items.remarks: Data Pump enables high-speed movement of data and metadata from one database to another. Data Pump allows users to unload/exfiltrate data from the database, so you should audit its usage. Unified auditing is the way to audit Data Pump actions.

items.summary: Oracle Recommended STIG Audit Policies exist but not all are enabled.
items.title: Audit STIG Actions
items.oneline: Enable STIG-related audit policies for STIG compliance
items.details: Oracle Recommended STIG Audit Policies found but are not enabled: ORA_STIG_RECOMMENDATIONS, ORA_ALL_TOPLEVEL_ACTIONS, ORA_LOGON_LOGOFF
items.remarks: To comply with STIG, DBMS must generate audit records for the DoD-selected list of auditable events. Oracle provides ORA_STIG_RECOMMENDATIONS, ORA_ALL_TOPLEVEL_ACTIONS and ORA_LOGON_LOGOFF policies that can be enabled to make the database STIG compliant.

items.summary: Found 5 unencrypted tablespaces. No encrypted columns found.
items.title: Transparent Data Encryption
items.oneline: Ensure tablespace encryption is used to secure data-at-rest
items.details:
Unencrypted tablespaces: SYSAUX, SYSTEM, TEMP, UNDOTBS1, USERS
Encrypted tablespaces: (none)

TABLESPACE_ENCRYPTION = MANUAL_ENABLE for databases running on-premises.
items.remarks:
Encryption of sensitive data is a requirement in most regulated environments. Transparent Data Encryption (TDE) automatically encrypts data as it is stored and decrypts it upon retrieval. TDE protects sensitive data from attacks that bypass the database and read data files directly. Encryption keys may be stored in wallets on the database server itself or stored remotely in Oracle Key Vault for improved security. Additionally, attackers often leverage non-encrypted sensitive data for extortion or threaten to release sensitive data publicly (ransomware). Encryption keys may be stored in wallets on the database server itself or stored remotely in Oracle Key Vault for improved security. The parameter TABLESPACE_ENCRYPTION supersedes (replaces) ENCRYPT_NEW_TABLESPACES and ensures that TDE tablespace encryption is applied to all newly created tablespaces. Setting TABLESPACE_ENCRYPTION parameter to AUTO_ENABLE or ENCRYPT_NEW_TABLESPACES parameter to ALWAYS is recommended in order to protect all data regardless of the options specified when the tablespace is created.

Starting with Oracle Database 23ai, the encryption algorithms 'SEED 128 bits key' and 'GOST 256 bits key' have been de-supported. 

With the exception of the HP Itanium platform, the GOST and SEED decryption libraries are deprecated with Oracle Database 23ai. Oracle recommends that you (online or offline) re-key TDE encrypted data with another algorithm at the earliest.

items.summary: Found 1 wallet. No wallets are stored in the data file directory.
items.title: Encryption Key Wallet
items.oneline: Check the location of your encryption wallet
items.details:
WALLET_ROOT init.ora parameter is not set.
Wallet type: FILE
Status: NOT_AVAILABLE
Wallet was created using mkstore utility.
Wallet order: SINGLE

Data file directory: /opt/oracle/product/23ai/dbhomeFree/dbs
items.remarks: Wallets are encrypted files that store encryption keys, passwords, and other sensitive data. You should not store wallet files in the same directory with database data files to avoid accidentally creating backups that include both encrypted data files and the wallet containing the master key protecting those files. Consider storing encryption keys in Oracle Key Vault instead of wallet files for maximum separation of keys and data.

items.summary: FIPS mode is disabled for Transparent Data Encryption (TDE) and DBMS_CRYPTO PL/SQL package.
items.title: FIPS Mode for TDE and DBMS_CRYPTO
items.oneline: Use FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic modules for STIG compliance
items.details: DBFIPS_140 = FALSE.
items.remarks: Federal Information Processing Standard (140-2) is a U.S. government security standard that specifies security requirements for cryptographic processing. It is used to approve cryptographic modules. Setting parameter DBFIPS_140 to TRUE enables Transparent Data Encryption (TDE) and DBMS_CRYPTO PL/SQL package program units to run in a FIPS-compliant mode. FIPS mode is mainly used by departments and agencies of the United States federal government looking to meet FIPS and/or STIG compliance.

items.summary: FIPS 140-2 authentication/encryption is not configured.
items.title: FIPS mode for TLS
items.oneline: Database network traffic should be protected through TLS
items.details: SSLFIPS_140 is not set (default value = FALSE).
items.remarks: Federal Information Processing Standard (140-2) is a U.S. government security standard that specifies security requirements. It is used to approve cryptographic modules. Setting parameter SSLFIPS_140 = TRUE makes Transport Layer Security (TLS) cryptographic operations take place in the underlying FIPS-certified library. The CPU accelerates these cryptographic operations when hardware acceleration is available and configured correctly in the host hardware and software. FIPS mode is mostly used by departments and agencies of the United States federal government looking to meet FIPS and/or STIG compliance.

items.summary: Examined 2 initialization parameters. No issues found.
items.title: Authentication Configuration
items.oneline: Check number of failed authentication attempts in a session
items.details:
SEC_MAX_FAILED_LOGIN_ATTEMPTS = 3
RESOURCE_LIMIT = TRUE
items.remarks:
SEC_MAX_FAILED_LOGIN_ATTEMPTS configures the maximum number of failed authentication attempts in a single session before the connection is closed.

This is independent of the user profile parameter FAILED_LOGIN_ATTEMPTS, which controls locking the user account after multiple failed login attempts. Not controlling failed login attempts before closing the connection and locking accounts after a number of failed logins opens the door for successful brute-force login and Denial-of-Service attacks. RESOURCE_LIMIT should be set to TRUE to enable enforcement of any resource constraints defined in user profiles.

items.summary: Oracle OS user will be used to interact with the operating system.
items.title: PDB OS User
items.oneline: Ensure the highly privileged Oracle OS user is not being used to run external OS jobs from the database
items.details: Operating system interactions are performed as the Oracle OS user.
items.remarks:
The PDB_OS_CREDENTIAL parameter determines the OS user for running external jobs from within the Oracle Database at operating system (OS) level. This parameter is set to a credential defined using the DBMS_CREDENTIAL package.

Allowing a job to execute at OS level using the default credential, Oracle OS user, or other OS administrative users may grant excessive privileges beyond necessary. Using a least privileged OS user defined by a specified credential value in the PDB_OS_CREDENTIAL parameter helps ensure that operating system interactions are performed with minimal privileges, providing more secure operating system interactions. You should create an OS user with minimum necessary privileges and use it to set the PDB_OS_CREDENTIAL parameter.

This approach helps protect data belonging to one PDB from being accessed by users connected to another PDB. A less privileged OS user also prevents unauthorized activities.

items.summary: Found 2 control files.
items.title: Control Files
items.oneline: Ensure control files have redundancy
items.details:
Control file(s) location: /opt/oracle/oradata/FREE/control01.ctl, /opt/oracle/oradata/FREE/control02.ctl

All control files are in same directory.
items.remarks: A control file tracks the physical components of the database. It is the root file that the database uses to find all the other files used by the database. Loss of access to the control files can affect database availability, integrity, and recovery. Due to the importance of the control file and to reduce the risk of losing it due to corruption, or accidental or intentional removal, Oracle recommends that the control file be multiplexed or have multiple identical copies. Organizations using RAID policies for multiplexing must review them to ensure control files are on separate, archived directories within one or more RAID devices.

items.summary: Found 3 redo log files.
items.title: Redo Log Files
items.oneline: Ensure redo log files have redundancy
items.details: Redo files: /opt/oracle/oradata/FREE/redo01.log, /opt/oracle/oradata/FREE/redo02.log, /opt/oracle/oradata/FREE/redo03.log
items.remarks: The redo log is the most crucial structure for recovery operations, which consists of two or more pre-allocated files that store all changes made to the database as they occur. Every instance of an Oracle Database has an associated redo log to protect the database in case of an instance failure. Redo logs should be multiplexed and stored on different physical disks.

items.summary: Database in NOARCHIVELOG mode.
items.title: Archive Log Mode
items.oneline: Archive log mode should be enabled
items.remarks: In NOARCHIVELOG mode, a clean shutdown and database shutdown are necessary to create a backup. If a failure occurs, restoring the whole database to the latest backup is the only recovery option. This mode may result in the loss of recent transactions. On the other hand, ARCHIVELOG mode allows backups during operation, ensuring the ability to recover the database to a specific point in time in the event of failure or data corruption.

items.summary: No Backup Records found for the last 90 days.
items.title: Database Backup
items.oneline: Ensure regular database backup
items.remarks:
You should backup the database regularly. Having a recent backup on a separate media will help you prevent data loss in a system failure and may help you quickly recover from a ransomware attack. Oracle Recovery Manager (RMAN) allows performing backup and recovery tasks on your databases. 

It is strongly recommended to use Transparent Data Encryption (TDE) or RMAN encrypted backups to ensure that malicious users cannot read backup data. Encrypting data at the source with TDE or RMAN protects local and subsequent offsite backups from the beginning of the backup lifecycle.

For continuous data protection and fast recovery against ransomware attacks, refer to Oracle Zero Data Loss Recovery Appliance, which provides immutable backups and deployment in network-isolated Cyber Vault architecture.

items.summary: Instance name does not contain database version number.
items.title: Instance Name Check
items.oneline: Database instance name should not contain version numbers
items.details:
Instance Name = FREE
Database Version = 23.6.0.24.10
items.remarks: Instance names should not contain Oracle Database version numbers. Unauthenticated users may discover service names. If the service name includes version numbers or other database product information, a malicious user may use that information to develop a targeted attack.

items.summary: SQL Firewall is not enabled.
items.title: SQL Firewall
items.oneline: Check SQL Firewall configuration
items.remarks: Built into Oracle Database kernel, SQL Firewall inspects all the incoming SQL statements and database connections and can detect and/or block unauthorized SQL and connections. SQL Firewall provides real time protection against common database attacks such as SQL Injection. Once activated, SQL Firewall will learn SQL and connection activities and build user based allow-lists from collected data; the allow-lists can be modified and enforced in a desired mode.

items.summary: Database has read/write ORACLE_HOME.
items.title: Read-only ORACLE_HOME
items.oneline: Check if ORACLE_HOME needs to be read-only
items.details: ORACLE_HOME: /opt/oracle/product/23ai/dbhomeFree
items.remarks: An Oracle home is a directory into which all Oracle software is installed. In a read-only Oracle home, all the configuration data and log files reside outside the read-only Oracle home directory. This feature allows you to use the read-only Oracle home as a software image that you can distribute across multiple servers. A read-only Oracle home also helps with seamless patching and updating of Oracle databases.

items.summary: Data inference attacks through SQL92_SECURITY are properly blocked.
items.title: Inference of Table Data
items.oneline: Enforce strict SQL92_SECURITY
items.details: SQL92_SECURITY = TRUE
items.remarks: When SQL92_SECURITY is set to TRUE, UPDATE and DELETE statements that refer to a column in their WHERE clauses will succeed only when the user has the privilege to SELECT from the same column. This parameter should be set to TRUE so that this requirement is enforced to prevent users from inferring the value of a column they do not have the privilege to view.

items.summary: The password file is configured correctly.
items.title: Access to Password File
items.oneline: Ensure administrative users are distinctly identified in password file
items.details: REMOTE_LOGIN_PASSWORDFILE = EXCLUSIVE
items.remarks: The REMOTE_LOGIN_PASSWORDFILE set to EXCLUSIVE allows the password file to contain distinct entries for each administrative user, allowing them to be individually audited and tracked for their actions. It also allows passwords to be updated using the ALTER USER command.

items.summary: Examined 4 initialization parameters that can be used to detect malformed packets from a client and found no issue.
items.title: Network Communication
items.oneline: Check remote listener and protocol error parameters
items.details:
REMOTE_LISTENER = (none)
SEC_PROTOCOL_ERROR_FURTHER_ACTION = (DROP,3)
SEC_PROTOCOL_ERROR_TRACE_ACTION = TRACE
SEC_RETURN_SERVER_RELEASE_BANNER = FALSE
items.remarks:
The REMOTE_LISTENER parameter is used to connect a client application to a database instance that is located on a different machine than the listener. In typical single-instance deployments, only a local listener is used, and this parameter should be unset. However, in high availability configurations such as Oracle Real Application Clusters (RAC) environments, the REMOTE_LISTENER parameter should be set. Please check RAC best practices to ensure all database instances can register with all the listener processes. This establishes client connections even if one listener process or database instance fails.

The SEC_PROTOCOL_ERROR parameters control the database server's response to malformed network packets from a client. The SEC_PROTOCOL_ERROR_FURTHER_ACTION parameter is set to DROP by default, and SEC_PROTOCOL_ERROR_TRACE_ACTION is set to TRACE. A malicious client attempting to attack the database may send malformed packets. To log the incident and terminate the connection, you should set these parameters appropriately.

Setting SEC_RETURN_SERVER_RELEASE_BANNER to FALSE is essential to limit the amount of information disclosed to an unauthenticated client. This parameter ensures that only minimal information is provided to the client, enhancing security by reducing the amount of information potential attackers can use.

items.summary: Examined 2 initialization parameters. No issues found.
items.title: External OS Authentication
items.oneline: Disable OS and network ability to manage roles
items.details:
REMOTE_OS_ROLES = FALSE
OS_ROLES = FALSE
items.remarks: The OS_ROLES parameter determines whether roles granted to users are controlled by GRANT statements in the database or by the database server's operating system. REMOTE_OS_AUTHENT and REMOTE_OS_ROLES allow the client operating system to set the database user and roles. All of these parameters should be set to FALSE so that the database manages the authorizations of database users.

items.details: Components/options not in use: Oracle Text, Oracle OLAP API, Spatial, Oracle Database Vault, Oracle Label Security
items.remarks: Database components provided by default may not be necessary to support essential application functionality. Applications should adhere to the principles of least functionality by providing only crucial capabilities. Therefore unused database components and options should be disabled or, if possible, removed.

items.remarks: The DBMS_SCHEDULER package is used to administer everyday job tasks. For example, to submit a job to job queues managed by the database. You should review scheduled jobs regularly to detect unauthorized job submissions. Also, you should check grants on DBMS_SCHEDULER to validate if only the necessary users have the grants to manage jobs in the database.

items.title: Triggers
items.oneline: Check need for disabled triggers
items.details: Disabled triggers: HR.SECURE_EMPLOYEES
items.remarks: A trigger is a stored procedure that the Oracle Database invokes automatically whenever a specified event occurs, such as inserting data in a table or connecting to the database. Disabled Oracle-provided triggers could be a potential cause for suspicion as the protection or monitoring they provided is disabled.

items.summary: No disabled constraints found.
items.title: Disabled Constraints
items.oneline: Check need for disabled constraints
items.remarks: Constraints enforce and guarantee specific relationships between data items stored in the database. Disabled constraints are a potential cause for concern because the conditions they ensure are not enforced.

items.summary: No external procedures found. No external services found.
items.title: External Procedures
items.oneline: Check need for unknown and untrusted external procedures
items.remarks: External procedures allow PL/SQL to execute code written in other languages. Ensure that you only make available for execution trusted code libraries. Although the database can spawn its own process to execute the external procedure, it is advisable to configure a listener service for this purpose so that the external code can run as a less privileged OS user. The listener configuration should set EXTPROC_DLLS to identify the specific shared library code that can be executed rather than using the default value ANY. Note that the database cannot control modifications to external code.

items.summary: Found 1 application schema that contain Program Units.
items.title: Source Code Analysis
items.oneline: Check sensitive data exposed through error messages in stored programs
items.details: Schema containing program units: HR
items.remarks: Messages generated by stored program units can inadvertently provide sensitive business, personal or system information that a malicious user can misuse. You should analyze the application code to verify that error messages do not contain information beyond what is needed for troubleshooting the issue. Program units should not access and print restricted user data.

items.summary: No database links found. Database link names may differ from the remote database connection they define.
items.title: Database Links
items.oneline: Check Database Links
items.details:
GLOBAL_NAMES = FALSE

Users with CREATE DATABASE LINK privilege: GSMADMIN_INTERNAL(*), GSMUSER(*), SYSTEM
Users with CREATE PUBLIC DATABASE LINK privilege: GSMADMIN_INTERNAL, SYSTEM
items.remarks:
Database links allow users to execute SQL statements referencing tables in other databases. This allows both querying and storing data on the remote database.

Public database links are visible to all users, while private database links are only visible to the link owner.

Avoid using public database links as much as possible, as all users who connect to the database will have access to them. This can create a potential security vulnerability if the appropriate access controls are not in place.

It is advisable to set GLOBAL_NAMES to TRUE to ensure that link names match the databases they access.

NETWORK_ACL_24B79454F8005247E06379D65E646F66 (Host: *, Ports: Min - Max)
Principal: GSMADMIN_INTERNAL, Action: deny, Privilege: resolve
items.remarks:
Network ACLs control users' access to external network services and resources from the database through PL/SQL network utility packages including UTL_TCP, UTL_HTTP, UTL_SMTP and UTL_INADDR.

You can grant or deny principals (users and roles) access to a specific network service on a particular port.

If you only need access to port 80, specify it. Avoid using wildcards, as you will have less control and might give access to more servers/ports than necessary.

Ensure permissions and access to network services are limited to the minimum needed for each user.

items.remarks: XML ACLs control access to database resources using the XML DB feature. Every resource in the Oracle XML DB Repository hierarchy has an associated ACL. The ACL mechanism specifies a privilege-based access control for resources to principals (database users or roles). A security check is performed whenever a resource is accessed, and the ACL determines if the requesting user has sufficient privileges to access the resource. Make sure that these privileges are limited to the minimum needed by each user.

items.summary: Native network encryption is accepted but not required. Integrity check using checksums is accepted but not required.
items.title: Network Encryption
items.oneline: Check configurations used for Native Network Encryption
items.details:
SQLNET.ENCRYPTION_SERVER is not set (default value = ACCEPTED).
SQLNET.CRYPTO_CHECKSUM_SERVER is not set (default value = ACCEPTED).


No valid listeners found.

SSL_CERT_REVOCATION is not set (default value = NONE).
items.remarks:
Network encryption is crucial for protecting the confidentiality and integrity of communication between a database server and its clients. To ensure that client connections are encrypted, you should configure either Native Encryption or TLS.

If using Native Encryption, it's essential to set both ENCRYPTION_SERVER and CRYPTO_CHECKSUM_SERVER to REQUIRED. Oracle Database servers and clients are configured to ACCEPT encrypted connections by default to make deployment and compatibility easier. This means you can enable encryption and integrity settings for a connection pair by configuring just one side of the connection (server-side or the client-side). For instance, if many Oracle clients connect to a database instance, you can configure the required encryption and integrity settings for all those connections by modifying the sqlnet.ora file on the server end. There's no need to make configuration changes for each client separately. However, remember that the risk of plaintext data passing over the network still exists.

Note that whether the security service is enabled depends on a combination of client and server configuration parameters.

If using TLS, it's crucial to specify TCPS for all network ports, and SSL_CERT_REVOCATION should be set to REQUIRED. Oracle recommends using TLS network encryption.

items.summary: Valid node check is not enabled and the server can accept connections from any client. Neither TCP.INVITED_NODES nor TCP.EXCLUDED_NODES is set.
items.title: Client Nodes
items.oneline: Check parameters to allow a client to connect
items.details:
TCP.VALIDNODE_CHECKING is not set (default value = NO). Recommended value is YES.
TCP.INVITED_NODES is not set.
TCP.EXCLUDED_NODES is not set.
items.remarks: TCP.VALIDNODE_CHECKING should be enabled to control which client nodes can connect to the database server. You can specify an allow list containing client nodes (IP Address/Hostname/Subnet) that are allowed to connect (TCP.INVITED_NODES) or a blocklist of nodes that are not allowed  (TCP.EXCLUDED_NODES). You should not configure both the invited and excluded nodes list. If that is the case, the database will use only the invited node list.

items.summary: Parameters governing unauthenticated connection(s) are configured properly.
items.title: Connection Limits Configuration
items.oneline: Check parameters that control connections waiting for authentication
items.details:
SQLNET.INBOUND_CONNECT_TIMEOUT is not set (default value = 60).
INBOUND_CONNECT_TIMEOUT_listener_name is not set (default value = 60).
SQLNET.EXPIRE_TIME is not set (default value is unlimited).
items.remarks: Unauthenticated connections can introduce possible denial-of-service attacks, wherein malicious clients attempt to flood database servers with connect requests that consume resources. Setting SQLNET.INBOUND_CONNECT_TIME ensures that the server terminates the connection if the necessary authentication information is not provided. Setting INBOUND_CONNECT_TIMEOUT_listener_name ensures that the listener terminates the connection if it does not receive the client request in the specified time.SQLNET.EXPIRE_TIME is used to specify a time interval to send a probe to verify that client/server connections are active.

items.remarks: These parameters are used to limit changes to the network listener configuration. ADMIN_RESTRICTIONS should be enabled to prevent parameter changes to the running listener. CONNECTION_RATE determines the rate enforced across all the endpoints that are rate limited.

items.summary: Only one database/instance configured on the host
items.title: Segregation of Production and Development Databases
items.oneline: Check presence of production and non-production databases on the same host
items.details: Database/instance on the host: (none)
items.remarks: Production and non-production databases must be segregated and not coexist in the same host. If a host contains both a development and a production database, determine if developers were granted elevated database and/or operating system privileges as they can affect the production database system's operation and/or security. Operating system and database privileges assigned to developers on shared development and production systems must be restricted. Any developer needing access to a production database should be authorized and documented. Consider using separate accounts for a person's developer and production duties. At a minimum, use distinct roles for developer and production privileges, audit their activity, and lock or drop their account after use. Review all user accounts and validate if there are any developer accounts in production databases.

items.remarks: The ORACLE_HOME directory and its subdirectories contain files critical to the correct operation of the database, including executable programs, libraries, data files, and configuration files.
